node.text: Take a sneak peek into the noisy cavern of the largest particle detector in the world @atlasexperiment with Theo Alexopoulos and @chit_chet_ and look at the experiment’s newest addition - the New Small Wheels 🔵

node.title: Live from the ATLAS Cavern and Small Wheels Lab

node.text:
With the Proton Synchrotron and its Booster accelerating protons to high energies again, the physics season can start at the ISOLDE radioactive ion beam facility. 💥💻 

During several #upgradingLHC activities, two new target stations have been installed at ISOLDE and protons are back for studying physics.

#PhotoOfTheWeek by @leauickque and @chit_chet_
🎵: Your Gain

node.title: Physics season at CERN’s ISOLDE facility

node.text:
CERN lays first stone of Science Gateway 🪨 

Scheduled to open in 2023, CERN is increasing its capacity to welcome visitors of all ages, from near and far and extending its educational portfolio with a view to increasingly inspiring future generations towards science and research. 

What are you most excited to see inside #CERNScienceGateway? 😀

🎥 by Titouan Robin Chapuis, @chit_chet_

node.text:
Happy 50th birthday hadron colliders! 🙌

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

50 years ago, CERN scientists collided particles in the first hadron collider ever built. On 27 January 1971, CERN’s Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR) produced the world’s first proton–proton collisions.
Physicists had planned this machine in the 1960s, based on the idea that smashing two particle beams head on would give much higher energies than colliding a single beam of particles with a fixed target. 

This first hadron collider helped change the views of members of the physics community, who doubted the usefulness of hadron colliders. By the time it shut down in 1984, it had produced many important results, including indications that protons contain smaller constituents, ultimately identified as quarks and gluons.

node.text:
Since the Standard Model leaves many questions unanswered, physicists have proposed theories that go beyond it, some of which explain the nature of dark matter. Among such theories are those suggesting the existence of axions or axion-like particles. These theories need to be tested, and many experiments have been set up around the world to look for these particles, including at CERN. 

One antimatter experiment at CERN, BASE, has now, for the first time, turned the tools developed to detect single antiprotons, the #antimatter equivalent of a proton, to the search for #darkmatter! 😍

node.text:
#Doyouknow why matter dominates over antimatter in the universe? 😲

This situation makes a detailed study of antimatter of immense significance not just for physics but also for cosmology. 🌌

25 years ago, CERN announced producing the first atoms of antimatter. This handful of antihydrogen atoms were created on the Low Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR), a machine used to accumulate and store antiprotons. The international team from @forschungszentrum_juelich, @uni_fau, @universeinthelab, and @unigenova led by Walter Oelert succeeded for the first time in linking an antiproton and a positron, but for a very short time. ⏱🔍

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

🎞 The experiment had only 48 hours of beam time during the very last months of the LEAR machine and its success opened the path to a new antimatter machine, the Antiproton Decelerator (AD), that hosts several experiments studying #antimatter today. 💯

node.title: First Atoms of Antimatter at CERN

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.

node.text:
Mens sana in corpore sano 🏉

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT

A sound mind in a sound body… These CERN rugby players in 1963 seem to have taken the well-known Latin expression at its word. 😉

As of today, the rugby club still exists at CERN. Other sports are also practised and allow people to meet outside of the office: yoga, cycling, volleyball, table tennis and a lot more. CERNois have quite eclectic tastes when it comes to sport! 

Tell us your favourite sport in the comments!

Photo by CERN in Meyrin, Switzerland. May be an image of tree, outdoors and text that says 'Accelerating Science Accélérateur de science ® home.'.

node.text:
Sunny weather is back at CERN! ☀️⠀
⠀
#PhotoOfTheWeek by @chit_chet_⠀
⠀
Summer at CERN is a time to share our love for high-energy physics. From June to August, we welcome Bachelor and Master’s degree students as part of our experimental, engineering or computing teams. 😎⠀
⠀
The Summer Student Programme 2021 will take place online this year. The participants will have the chance to work with some of the latest technologies and attend lectures given by some of the foremost experts in the field!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

node.text:
#Onthisday in 1902, the theoretical physicist Paul Dirac was born.⠀
⠀
In 1928, Dirac wrote an equation that described an electron moving at a relativistic speed. This equation had not one, but two solutions: one for an electron with positive energy, and one for an electron with negative energy. 🤔 It was the first time the existence of an "antielectron", or "positron" was considered. ⠀
⠀
In 1933, Dirac won the @nobelprize_org for his equation and became known as the father of #antimatter physics.⠀
⠀
Today the AEGIS experiment at CERN uses a beam of antiprotons to measure Earth's gravitational acceleration.⠀
⠀
📸 by @max.brice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CERN on August 06, 2021 tagging @infn_insights, and @lnf_infn. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
This is a close-up of the RF-gun microwave cavity of a new radiofrequency photo-injector, which arrived from the National Laboratory of Frascati in Italy. 

This radiofrequency photo-injector will be used to build a prototype injector for testing in  CLEAR, the CERN Linear Electron Accelerator for Research. ⚙️

CLEAR is composed of a 20-metre-long linear accelerator followed by a 20-metre-long experimental beamline that can host several experiments. It is a unique facility for fast and efficient beam-based research. 

📸: Brice, Maximilien/CERN

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 05, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
A projection booth at CERN? 🎞 ⠀
⠀
#ThowbackThursday to December 1972: this picture doesn’t show the backstage of a retro cinema, but rather the ERASME machine. ⠀
⠀
Designed to handle film from the Big European Bubble Chamber, ERASME was a marvel of technology at the time: it combined a scanning and measuring system, meaning that it could do a sequence of operations that had previously been done separately. ⠀
⠀
This complex system read the particle tracks by means of a light spot generated by a high precision cathode ray tube, and then reconstructed the collision event in three dimensions with the help of a computer. This is how we accessed the sub-nuclear world almost 50 years ago!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 04, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
AWAKE awakes 😉⠀
 ⠀
After the 2-year period of #upgradingLHC Long Shutdown, the AWAKE experiment started its second run last week. This run aims to achieve high-charge bunches of electrons accelerated to high energies while maintaining the beam quality and to show the scalability of the acceleration process.⠀
 ⠀
AWAKE is the world’s first proton-driven plasma wakefield acceleration experiment. It investigates the use of plasma wakefields driven by a proton bunch to accelerate charged particles. The R&D project of this accelerator seeks to allow future colliders to achieve higher energies over shorter distances than currently possible. 🤩⠀
 ⠀
#PhotoOfTheWeek by @max.brice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on July 30, 2021.

node.text:
This is the A-side of the new Fast Interaction Trigger (FIT), a detector designed as part of the @alice_experiment upgrades. It was recently installed in the ALICE cavern. 👨‍🏭

When the LHC restarts, FIT will provide information on beam luminosity and collision time. To deliver the measurements, the FIT uses three different detector technologies: a scintillator detector, Cherenkov detectors, and scintillator arrays. A new, faster electronics and readout system has also been developed for this upgrade. 

This picture shows one of the Cherenkov detectors and the scintillator detector. They are placed 3.5 meters away from the collision point. 💥

📸: Trzaska, Wladyslaw Henryk/CERN

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
Steven Weinberg (1933-2021) 💫

One of the greatest theoretical physicists of all times passed away last week . Steven Weinberg is most known for the unified theory of weak and electromagnetic forces that earned him the @nobelprize_org in 1979. 

In this #ThrowbackThursday, Steven Weinberg had just got back from Stockholm to collect his prize, and later gave the seminar “The rise and fall of baryon number" at CERN. His audience remained fascinated during the whole conference: it is not everyday that you meet someone who has radically changed the way we look at the universe! 🌟

node.text:
Guess what this is 🔎 

These cylindrical tubes covered in aluminum are part of CERN’s neutron time-of-flight facility’s third generation spallation target. They belong to the nitrogen gas cooling system of this machine designed to produce a neutron beam.
 
The n_TOF facility studies neutron-nucleus interactions. It contributes to the measurement of nuclear data but also produces data used in astrophysics and hadron therapy. 
 
The new lead-based and nitrogen cooled n_TOF spallation target that you see in this photo has received its first proton beam after #upgradingLHC! 🌟

Photo by CERN on July 23, 2021.
A scientist is analyzing samples of water.

node.text:
#ThrowbackThursday to water sampling in 1975 👩‍🔬
 
The first photo shows a scientist analysing water samples from Lake Geneva and from the Lyon river. In the second photo, she is collecting samples from the river, near CERN’s North Experimental Hall. 🔬
 
CERN manages its environmental footprint responsibly by collecting and analysing many water samples every year. CERN recently published its first public environmental report, which also includes innovations made at CERN that are being adapted for environmental protection. 

#CERNImpact
